title: Future Fund won't yield to climate activists
text:
Future Fund chief investment officer Raphael Arndt said that its external fund managers and companies disclosing their carbon exposure was most important for long-term investments in infrastructure and shares, not so much for short-term arbitrage investments.

"The future path of carbon pricing and the market reaction to that is a long run risk that we have to take into account, just like many other long run risks," Dr Arndt said.

Greens fret on 'social cost'

Mr Whish-Wilson told Mr Neal that there was a "social cost" to burning fossil fuels and the fund could play a leading role in more disclosure.

"I understand that would be challenging, but you would be taking the lead on a very important issue that's continuing to build in importance and momentum around the world, especially by financial regulators," Senator Whish-Wilson said.

Mr Neal said the Future Fund consulted with external fund managers it hired to ensure they understood the risks climate change posed to the investment portfolio from regulatory change, physical impacts and energy transitions.

"We seek to make sure those things are understood and factored into the prices we pay for the assets, so it's integrated into our decision making," he said.

Finance Minister Mathias Cormann, who is the government minister responsible for the Future Fund, said: "The world continues to rely, to a large degree, on fossil fuels across a whole range of areas and will continue to for the forseeable future."

"It is absolutely an appropriate activity for the Future Fund to be invested in."

Mr Neal said the fund supported companies disclosing their risks to help inform the efficient market pricing of assets, in line with the international taskforce's standardised approach.

"Nobody buys and sells the Future Fund so that sort of disclosure, from our perspective, is not contributing to market efficiency and is a considerable overhead," Mr Neal said.

"The market needs to find a way of making appropriate disclosures that aren't overly onerous on the corporate world because there are significant costs that come with that."

The Future Fund invests via more than 100 fund managers across 16 asset classes, including equities, infrastructure, emerging markets and private equity.

"One of the challenges for us is we invest across all of the different asset classes and many different fund managers, across different types of structures where you get access to information at different levels," Mr Neal said.

"It would be a very significant challenge for us to try and bring all that together into a single set of scenarios."

The Future Fund in 2013 excluded tobacco producers from its investment list.

Climate activist pressure

Investment funds and climate activists around the world are pressuring listed companies, including mining giants such as BHP and Rio Tinto, to publish more information about their exposure to climate change risks and carbon-intensive energy sources.

It follows the $43 billion industry superannuation fund manager, Hostplus chief investment officer Sam Sicilia, last month declaring that divesting coal shares was a "waste of time" because those shares will be bought by other investors, with the associated emissions therefore continuing unabated.

The Future Fund, founded in 2006 by then-treasurer Peter Costello to strengthen the Commonwealth’s long-term financial position, has earned a 10 per cent annual return over 10 years, easily exceeding its benchmark target of 6.5 per cent a year.

Australia's financial regulators have also backed the G20 Financial Stability Board’s Taskforce on Climate Related Financial Disclosures, an international business-led initiative chaired by billionaire businessman Michael Bloomberg and including some of the world's largest financial institutions.

The Australian Securities and Investments Commission's guidance for retail investors, RG 228, now contains a section warning the transition to a lower-carbon economy "may entail extensive policy, legal, technology and market changes to address mitigation and adaption requirements related to climate change".
description: The $166 billion sovereign wealth fund has ruled out boycotting fossil fuel investments and rejected a Greens push to disclose its exposure to climate change risks.
